Further, Dr. Morrell says, “As we grapple with our national grief, confusion, and ongoing protest related to the senseless murders of unarmed Black and Brown men, women, and children, at the hands of those who are supposed to protect and serve, it is even more vitally important that we engage our young scholars in diverse, culturally responsive, emancipatory literature and curriculum resources such as the 1619 Project, that provide counter narratives and diverse perspectives on the legacy of slavery and its nexus to the status quo racial inequalities that we continue to experience today. Only when scholars of color can also see themselves within the curriculum, and as historical contributors to the “American story”, can they begin to see themselves as leaders with viable solutions that move themselves, our communities of color and our entire country forward toward true freedom and equality.”

https://twitter.com/pulitzercenter
